newsitem.title: USA: Sprint confident in PCS despite pressure.
newsitem.headline: Sprint confident in PCS despite pressure.

text.p: Sprint Corp said Tuesday start-up costs for personal communications services (PCS) will continue to pressure net earnings in 1997 and 1998, but the company remains confident in the wireless phone business.
"The start-up costs will cause pressure on earnings, and those will actually peak in 1998," Ronald LeMay, president and chief operating officer, said in an interview.

Sprint PCS, a joint venture including Sprint, Tele-Communications Inc, Cox Communications Inc and Comcast Corp, launched a wireless phone service in eight markets in 1996 and plans to launch the remaining markets by the end of the year, he said.

The venture won the rights to 65 major markets in a U.S. Federal Communications Commission auction of the wireless licenses, and Sprint said it alone acquired licenses as well in a recent auction for 139 additional markets.
Sprint PCS cost the company about $0.10 a share in 1996's fourth quarter.
At least one analyst cut his earnings estimate for 1998 because of the expected increase in dilution from the buildout of Sprint's territories following the auctions.
LeMay declined to comment on rumors that Sprint has considered buying a larger stake in the Sprint PCS venture from its other partners. It currently owns 40 percent.
Analysts have said it is a possibility in the long term, as start-up costs begin to slow.
"We have said repeatedly that we like the business very much," LeMay said of PCS. "We're very confident in those businesses and they're very strategic to Sprint."
And analysts said investors see PCS as a key business for the company.
"The bottom line is that by mid-year Sprint is going to trade on the subscriber growth in PCS," said Michael Elling, an analyst for Prudential Securities.

Earlier, Sprint reported fourth quarter net earnings of $0.57 a share including a litigation charge versus a net loss of $0.98 reflecting restructuring expenses. Operating income from continuing operations, before charges and ventures, rose to $347 million from $290 million.
Sprint has been quick to point out that despite the pressure on net earnings associated with new ventures, its core businesses continue to grow.
"The way I would summarize it is we have extremely strong momentum," LeMay said.

And Wall Street seems to agree. Despite the fourth quarter results coming in slightly lower than overall expectations because of the new investments and start-up costs, Sprint stock traded up 3/4 at 41.
"The core business was an absolute blow-out," Elling said.
